Stem: Slender, narrowly winged and nearly hairless, they form dense mats.
Leaves: Alternately arranged, 1.5-6 cm long, variable but often oblong or arrowhead shaped.
Flowers: Five fused white to pink petals, in clusters of 2 to 4, only open for one day and close in dull weather.
FruitSeeds: Hairless capsules, spherical, browning when mature, with 2-4 rough or warty seeds.
Habitat: Roadsides, rail lines, neglected urban areas.
DistinguishingFeatures: Larger flowers than native bindweeds, flower does not have bracts like Greater bindweed (*Calystegia silvatica*).
Impacts: Reduces agricultural yield, outcompetes native vegetation, harbours pests and diseases, may cause intestinal issues for stock.
